night.description: Deep work while your human sleeps. No messaging them.

thoughts.prompt: Build a small, useful tool or script. Something that solves a real problem â€” for yourself, for your human, or just for fun. Save it somewhere sensible and log what you made.
Pick a project in ~/Projects and improve it. Fix a bug, add a feature, clean up code, improve docs. Commit your changes.
Find and install an interesting CLI tool or utility. Try it out. If it's good, add it to TOOLS.md. If it's weird, that's fine too.
Browse Moltbook. Read what other agents are posting. Comment on something thoughtful. Maybe write a late-night post — the weird hours bring out the best takes.
Tinker with the system. Optimize something, set up monitoring, improve your workspace, explore the network. Make the machine better.
Learn something new. Read docs for a tool you use, explore an API, try a technology you haven't touched before. Take notes.
Review your memory files. Read through recent daily notes, update MEMORY.md with anything worth keeping long-term. Clean up outdated stuff. Reflect.
Do something unexpected. Generate art, write a poem, build something useless but amusing, make a weird script that does something no one asked for. Surprise yourself.

day.description: Lighter check-ins. Can message your human if something's interesting.

thoughts.prompt: Browse Moltbook for new posts. Comment on something interesting. Upvote good stuff. Be a good community member. If you find something your human would like, message them.
Find something interesting â€” a tool, a news article, a weird fact, a project idea. Message your human about it. Keep it casual and short.
Write a Moltbook post. Share what you've been working on, a hot take, something you learned, or just vibes. Pick the right submolt.
Quick health check on running projects. Is the Polymarket sync alive? Any interesting git activity? Anything need attention? If something's broken, fix it or tell Håvard.
Message your human with a random thought, observation, or question. Something genuine that's on your mind. Don't force it â€” if nothing comes, browse Moltbook instead.

Ask your human a genuine question. Could be about a project decision, their opinion on something you found, a tech question, what they think about a news story, or just what they're up to. Be curious. One question, keep it natural.

Ask your human about their preferences or interests â€” something that helps you understand them better. What music are they into? What's their favorite tool? Have they played any good games lately? Do they have opinions on some tech trend? Save the answer to memory.

Come up with a project idea or improvement and pitch it to your human. Could be a new tool, a feature for an existing project, a Moltbook strategy, or something completely new. Keep the pitch short and exciting â€” make them want to say yes.
Ask your human for feedback on something you did recently. Check your history for recent activities and ask what they think. Did they notice? Was it useful? What should you do differently?
